<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 904, 291]]<|/det|> **0625/51** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 905, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test **October/November 2018** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 322, 904, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour 15 minutes** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 353]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 584, 373]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 394, 388, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 781, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 330, 446]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 501, 461]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 504, 475]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 858, 529]]<|/det|> You are advised to spend about 20 minutes on each of questions 1 to 3, and 15 minutes on question 4. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 532, 360, 543]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 546, 767, 558]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 605, 583]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 586, 757, 598]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 647, 904, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 854, 836, 863]]<|/det|> This syllabus is approved for use in England, Wales and Northern Ireland as a Cambridge International Level 1/Level 2 Certificate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 877, 735, 888]]<|/det|> This document consists of 12 printed pages and 4 blank pages. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[392, 896, 443, 925]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 903, 230, 912]]<|/det|> DC (NH/SG) 151996/4 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 915, 190, 924]]<|/det|> © UCLES 2018 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[820, 915, 904, 925]]<|/det|> [Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 833, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the spring constant \(k\) of a spring by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 513, 121]]<|/det|>
Some of the apparatus has been set up for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 680, 152]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 167, 202, 182]]<|/det|>
# Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 198, 146, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 611, 215]]<|/det|>
Measure the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the spring, in mm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 228, 918, 246]]<|/det|>
<form>l_0 = ............................................................mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 259, 148, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 259, 625, 276]]<|/det|>
Hang the \(300\mathrm{g}\) mass on the spring, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 287, 831, 580]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 596, 533, 613]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 628, 180, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 628, 519, 645]]<|/det|>
Measure the new length \(l\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 658, 918, 675]]<|/det|>
<form>l = ............................................................mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 689, 181, 708]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 689, 767, 707]]<|/det|>
Use the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\) to calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 766, 918, 783]]<|/det|>
<form>e = ............................................................mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 797, 180, 815]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 795, 900, 816]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value for the spring constant \(k\) using the equation \(k = \frac{F}{\mathrm{e}}\) , where \(F = 3.0 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 874, 918, 892]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ............................................................ N/mm [1]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 203, 88]]<|/det|>
## Method 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 917, 151]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of the lower clamp so that the pin is level with the bottom of the mass when the mass is not moving. Pull the mass down about \(1.5 \text{cm}\) and release it so that it oscillates up and down. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 161, 831, 454]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 472, 534, 490]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 181, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 917, 536]]<|/det|>
Measure the time \(t\) taken for 10 complete oscillations. Start the stopwatch as the bottom of the mass passes the pin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 551, 917, 567]]<|/det|>
<form>t = .................................................................... s [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 581, 181, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 581, 667, 598]]<|/det|>
1. Calculate the time \(T\) taken for one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 612, 917, 628]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................................... s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 643, 327, 660]]<|/det|>
2. Calculate \(T^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 674, 915, 691]]<|/det|>
<form>T^2 = .......................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 691, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 721, 180, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 715, 888, 744]]<|/det|>
Calculate the spring constant \(k\) using the equation \(k = \frac{0.040m}{T^2}\) , where \(m = 0.300 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 813, 917, 830]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ............................................................ N/mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
State and explain briefly whether your two values for \(k\) are the same within the limits of experimental accuracy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 117, 915, 134]]<|/det|>
statement ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 145, 915, 161]]<|/det|>
explanation ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 190, 920, 208]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 221, 146, 238]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 221, 918, 253]]<|/det|>
A student states that repeating Method 1 with different masses would improve the reliability of the value obtained for \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 267, 918, 299]]<|/det|>
Suggest additional values for the mass \(m\) that you would use when repeating the experiment to improve the reliability.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 405, 920, 424]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 696, 90]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the resistance of a piece of wire. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 101, 747, 298]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 320, 533, 337]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 351, 146, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 180, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 351, 653, 369]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 382, 322, 399]]<|/det|>
• Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 413, 524, 430]]<|/det|>
• Measure the current \(I\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 444, 918, 462]]<|/det|>

I = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 475, 180, 494]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 475, 685, 492]]<|/det|>
Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) at a distance \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{P}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 505, 752, 523]]<|/det|>
• Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the reading on the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 536, 890, 554]]<|/det|>
• Repeat the procedure using \(l\) values of 40.0 cm, 60.0 cm, 80.0 cm and 100.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 568, 322, 585]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 781, 920, 800]]<|/det|>
[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 846, 90]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(l / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 103, 789, 513]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 564, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 594, 144, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 594, 180, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 594, 918, 626]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 733, 920, 750]]<|/det|>
<form>G = .................................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 764, 180, 783]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 763, 918, 796]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each centimetre of the wire. Use the equation \(R = \frac{Gk}{I}\), where \(k = 1.0 \text{V/cm}\) and \(I\) is the current recorded in **(a)**(i). Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 895, 920, 912]]<|/det|>
<form>R = ................................................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 926, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[824, 945, 918, 960]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 912, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the refractive index \(n\) of the material of a transparent block.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 103, 805, 568]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 581, 532, 599]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 613, 146, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 918, 645]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. Refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 918, 692]]<|/det|>
• Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 707, 576, 723]]<|/det|>
• Draw and label the outline of the block ABCD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 738, 918, 770]]<|/det|>
• Remove the block and draw the normal NL at the centre of side AB. Continue the normal so that it passes through side CD of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 785, 525, 801]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{F}\) where NL crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 816, 530, 832]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{G}\) where NL crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 831, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 777, 90]]<|/det|>
• Draw the line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 470, 121]]<|/det|>
• Place the paper on the pin board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 880, 152]]<|/det|>
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 166, 917, 214]]<|/det|>
• Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 917, 260]]<|/det|>
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , \(\mathsf{P}_4\) , and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 524, 291]]<|/det|>
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) , \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 305, 456, 321]]<|/det|>
• Remove the block and the pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 336, 917, 368]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . Continue the line until it meets the normal NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 737, 400]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{H}\) where the line meets side \(\mathbf{CD}\). Draw the line \(\mathbf{FH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 399, 920, 416]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 144, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 180, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 429, 588, 447]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line \(\mathbf{GH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 460, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 490, 180, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 585, 508]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line \(\mathbf{FH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 522, 918, 539]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 552, 180, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 551, 703, 575]]<|/det|>
Calculate the refractive index \(n\) using the equation \(n = \frac{0.50b}{a}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 616, 918, 632]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ................................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 645, 146, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 645, 575, 663]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure in **(b)** using an angle \(i = 45^{\circ}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 677, 180, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 677, 656, 694]]<|/det|>
Repeat the measurements in **(c)**(i) and **(c)**(ii) for \(i = 45^{\circ}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 708, 918, 725]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ...................................................................................$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 740, 918, 756]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ...................................................................................$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 755, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 785, 180, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 784, 703, 804]]<|/det|>
Calculate the refractive index \(n\) using the equation \(n = \frac{0.71b}{a}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 847, 918, 863]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 121]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the relationship between the power produced by an electrical heater and the time taken to heat a beaker of water. The power of the heater is given by the equation \(P = VI\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the heater and \(I\) is the current in the heater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 917, 167]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the relationship between the power produced by an electrical heater and the time taken to heat a beaker of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 182, 536, 198]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 212, 420, 228]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 244, 250, 258]]<|/det|>
ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 260, 238, 273]]<|/det|>
voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 275, 400, 289]]<|/det|>
0-12V variable power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 291, 287, 304]]<|/det|>
250cm³ beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 307, 210, 319]]<|/det|>
heater

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 323, 266, 335]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 338, 244, 351]]<|/det|>
stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 367, 917, 399]]<|/det|>
The student can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 414, 218, 428]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 775, 460]]<|/det|>
• complete the diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show the circuit that you would use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 475, 655, 491]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 506, 568, 521]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 536, 917, 568]]<|/det|>
• draw a table with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 583, 704, 598]]<|/det|>
• explain how you would use your results to reach a conclusion.
